@graph.d3f:definition: Access mediation is the process of granting or denying specific requests to: 1) obtain and use information and related information processing services; and 2) enter specific physical facilities (e.g., Federal buildings, military establishments, border crossing entrances).
@graph.rdfs:label: Access Mediation

@graph.d3f:definition: Access policy administration is the systematic process of defining, implementing, and managing access control policies that dictate user permissions to resources.
@graph.rdfs:label: Access Policy Administration

@graph.d3f:definition: Application code which prevents its own subroutines from accessing intra-process / internal memory space.
@graph.rdfs:label: Application-based Process Isolation

@graph.d3f:definition: Broadcast isolation restricts the number of computers a host can contact on their LAN.
@graph.rdfs:label: Broadcast Domain Isolation

@graph.d3f:definition: Limiting the transmission of a credential to a scoped set of relying parties.
@graph.rdfs:label: Credential Transmission Scoping

@graph.d3f:definition: Permitting only approved domains and their subdomains to be resolved.
@graph.rdfs:label: DNS Allowlisting

@graph.d3f:definition: Blocking DNS Network Traffic based on criteria such as IP address, domain name, or DNS query type.
@graph.rdfs:label: DNS Denylisting

@graph.d3f:definition: Restricting inter-domain trust by modifying domain configuration.
@graph.rdfs:label: Domain Trust Policy

@graph.d3f:definition: Filtering incoming email traffic based on specific criteria.
@graph.rdfs:label: Email Filtering

@graph.d3f:definition: Encrypted encapsulation of routable network traffic.
@graph.rdfs:label: Encrypted Tunnels

@graph.d3f:definition: Endpoint-based web server access mediation regulates web server access directly from user endpoints by implementing mechanisms such as client-side certificates and endpoint security software to authenticate devices and ensure compliant access.
@graph.rdfs:label: Endpoint-based Web Server Access Mediation

@graph.d3f:definition: Using a digital signature to authenticate a file before opening.
@graph.rdfs:label: Executable Allowlisting

@graph.d3f:definition: Blocking the execution of files on a host in accordance with defined application policy rules.
@graph.rdfs:label: Executable Denylisting

@graph.d3f:definition: Execution Isolation techniques prevent application processes from accessing non-essential system resources, such as memory, devices, or files.
@graph.rdfs:label: Execution Isolation

@graph.d3f:definition: Blocking a lookup based on the query's domain name value.
@graph.rdfs:label: Forward Resolution Domain Denylisting

@graph.d3f:definition: Blocking a DNS lookup's answer's IP address value.
@graph.rdfs:label: Forward Resolution IP Denylisting

@graph.d3f:definition: Preventing one process from writing to the memory space of another process through hardware based address manager implementations.
@graph.rdfs:label: Hardware-based Process Isolation

@graph.d3f:definition: Blocking the resolution of any subdomain of a specified domain name.
@graph.rdfs:label: Hierarchical Domain Denylisting

@graph.d3f:definition: Blocking DNS queries that are deceptively similar to legitimate domain names.
@graph.rdfs:label: Homoglyph Denylisting

@graph.d3f:definition: Limiting access to computer input/output (IO) ports to restrict unauthorized devices.
@graph.rdfs:label: IO Port Restriction

@graph.d3f:definition: Restricting network traffic originating from untrusted networks destined towards a private host or enclave.
@graph.rdfs:label: Inbound Traffic Filtering

@graph.d3f:definition: Using kernel-level capabilities to isolate processes.
@graph.rdfs:label: Kernel-based Process Isolation

@graph.d3f:definition: LAN access mediation encompasses the application of strict access control policies, systematic verification of devices, and authentication mechanisms to govern connectivity to a Local Area Network.
@graph.rdfs:label: LAN Access Mediation

@graph.d3f:definition: Restricting access to a local file by configuring operating system functionality.
@graph.rdfs:label: Local File Access Mediation

@graph.d3f:definition: Restricting access to a local file by configuring operating system functionality.
@graph.rdfs:label: Local File Permissions

@graph.d3f:definition: Network access mediation is the control method for authorizing access to a system by a user (or a process acting on behalf of a user) communicating through a network, including a local area network, a wide area network, and the Internet.
@graph.rdfs:label: Network Access Mediation

@graph.d3f:definition: Network Isolation techniques prevent network hosts from accessing non-essential system network resources.
@graph.rdfs:label: Network Isolation

@graph.d3f:definition: Control of access to organizational systems and services by users or processes over a network.
@graph.rdfs:label: Network Resource Access Mediation

@graph.d3f:definition: Restricting network traffic originating from any location.
@graph.rdfs:label: Network Traffic Filtering

@graph.d3f:definition: Restricting network traffic originating from a private host or enclave destined towards untrusted networks.
@graph.rdfs:label: Outbound Traffic Filtering

@graph.d3f:definition: Physical access mediation is the process of granting or denying specific requests to enter specific physical facilities (e.g., Federal buildings, military establishments, border crossing entrances.)
@graph.rdfs:label: Physical Access Mediation

@graph.d3f:definition: Proxy-based web server access mediation focuses on the regulation of web server access through intermediary proxy servers.
@graph.rdfs:label: Proxy-based Web Server Access Mediation

@graph.d3f:definition: Remote file access mediation is the process of managing and securing access to file systems over a network to ensure that only authorized users or processes can interact with remote files.
@graph.rdfs:label: Remote File Access Mediation

@graph.d3f:definition: Blocking a reverse lookup based on the query's IP address value.
@graph.rdfs:label: Reverse Resolution IP Denylisting

@graph.d3f:definition: Routing access mediation is a network security approach that manages and controls access at the network layer using VPNs, tunneling protocols, firewall rules, and traffic inspection to ensure secure and efficient data routing.
@graph.rdfs:label: Routing Access Mediation

@graph.d3f:definition: Controlling access to local computer system resources with kernel-level capabilities.
@graph.rdfs:label: System Call Filtering

@graph.d3f:definition: Restricting a user account's access to resources.
@graph.rdfs:label: User Account Permissions

@graph.d3f:definition: Web session access mediation secures user sessions in web applications by employing robust authentication and integrity validation, along with adaptive threat mitigation techniques, to ensure that access to web resources is authorized and protected from session-related attacks.
@graph.rdfs:label: Web Session Access Mediation

@graph.d3f:definition: The isolate tactic creates logical or physical barriers in a system which reduces opportunities for adversaries to create further accesses.
@graph.rdfs:label: Isolate
